titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. This being the day upon which by the Constitution of the United States, the annual Session of Congress was to commence, at eleven O’Clock this morning I attended at the Capitol—a Quorum of both Houses was formed; and the usual communications between them to that effect were had— A joint Committee to inform the President that Congress were ready to receive his Message was raised, and soon after reported that he would send it to-morrow at 12. O’Clock— The Resolve to furnish the members with newspapers; and that for daily pay to the Serjeant at arms pass’d—on which—Senate adjourn’d— I called on Mr: Smith, the Secretary of the Navy, but did not find him at home— The Vice-President, and nineteen members of the Senate were this day present.

2. At noon this day the President’s Message was received and read; with a few accompanying papers— The Message is long, and with regard to the negotiations both with Spain and England, gives no satisfactory information— The rest is principally speculative— I went to Georgetown after the adjournment of the Senate; which was immediately after the reading of the message and Papers— In the Evening, Mr: Boyd was below— I wrote to my wife.

3. We had a snow-storm, which continued the whole day and Evening— I attended however in Senate— A Message was received from the President, recommending the temporary suspension of the non-importation Act— Mr: Sayres was chosen chaplain to the Senate— I received a letter from Mr: May of Alexandria, from which I find that neither of the boxes of books I ship’d for the Library of Congress has arrived— I fear that which first was sent is lost— Dined at Mr: Boyd’s— Home early in the Evening— Wrote and read a little.

4. The business still languishes very much in Senate— Dr: Mitchill moved for the appointment of two Committees upon certain parts of the President’s Message— And Mr: Tracy moved a Resolution to call upon the President for papers respecting the negotiation with Great-Britain, and the recommendation to suspend the non-importation Act— Adjourned about Noon— I went into the lobby of the House of Representatives, where I found nothing doing, and where they soon adjourned also— In the Evening I read Gedoyn’s Quinctilian, and wrote a few observations on Homer’s Odyssey.— Finished reading the third Book, in Greek. I make in reading cursory remarks, which I find I lose almost entirely because not committed to writing when made— But in sitting down to write them, they multiply upon me so fast that I am soon arrested by the want of Time.

5. Dr: Mitchill’s Committee on the part of the Message relative to fortifications, was appointed— The motion for the other was postponed, as was Mr. Tracy’s motion for papers—at his own desire— Adjourned— I went into the lobby of the House, where they were debating the Bill to suspend the non-importation Act— I did not stay long— Called at the Bank to receive the dividend upon Blanchard’s power; and found a link deficient in the authentication of the power— Called at the Comptroller’s Office to enquire if the power could not be admitted as it is— He was not there— Stop’d about half an hour at Mr: Boyd’s— In the Morning I had seen Mr: R. Smith the Secretary of the Navy; to recommend Mr: English’s application for his nephew James Reilly— Promised the first vacancy in the Corps of Midshipmen— Wrote to Mr: English— Mr: Stoddert returned my visit this afternoon, and sat with us a couple of hours— Evening in my chamber— All day unwell, with a dull head-ache.

6. The Senate having adjourned over untill Monday, I pass’d this whole day at home; busily employed in my chamber— I began the fair copy of my Lecture 12. which has been too long delayed— And finished reading the 3d: Book of Gedoyn’s Quinctilian— These, with my daily morning readings, and my notes on the Odyssey left no part of the day idle.

7. Heard Mr: Sayrs at Georgetown; who notified his Congregation that he should during the Session, preach every second Sunday at the Capitol— The remainder of the day I spent at home in my chamber— The coldness of the weather made me less assiduous at my studies— Received this Evening a letter from Mrs: Adams— The first since I left Boston— Continued my lecture and my notes on the Odyssey.

8. The bill to suspend the non-importation Act came from the House of Representatives— Mr: Tracy’s motion for a call of papers, was debated and negatived— Two or three Committees appointed; and Mr: Bradley’s bill to prohibit the slave-trade, read the first time— Adjourned about 2. O’Clock— Remainder of the day reading and writing in my chamber.

9. The suspension bill was read the second time— Committed; reported on, and passed to the third reading— After the adjournment I called at the Comptroller’s Office, to enquire whether he would admit the power from N. Blanchard; but he suggested the propriety of enquiring of Mr: Seaver for a certificate that Mr: White was a Justice of the Peace— Spent the Evening at Captain Tingey’s, where I went with Mrs: Johnson, and all the young ladies— The company consisted principally of the naval Officers— I play’d a game of chess with Dr: Thornton.

10. At the third reading of the Bill to suspend the non-importation Act, an amendment was proposed, which was committed with the Bill— A memorial requesting the establishment of an uniform system of weights and measures was referred to a Committee of five— In the Evening, I finished the fair copy of my 12th. and began the 13th: lecture— Had no spare time to read.

11. A stormy day of Snow and Hail— There was scarcely any thing done in the Senate— I dined with Mr: Hellen at Mr: Boyd’s, and we spent the first part of the Evening there— Of course I had little time left for reading—

12. The storm continued through the whole of this day— I attended however in Senate— The Suspension-bill pass’d with an amendment; and without a dissenting voice— No other business done— Evening at home—chiefly in my chamber, writing. But failed of time for reading— Wrote to Mrs: Adams—

13. I had intended to have visited Mr: Foxhall’s foundery of Cannon at Georgetown; but was prevented by the weather; which confined me this whole day to the house— I employed it without any loss of time, in writing upon my lecture, and in reading Quinctilian— Mr: Van Cortlandt was below this Evening; but I did not see him—

14. Mr: Boyd called here this morning— I heard Mr: Laurie at the Treasury-Office, and afterwards returned the visits of Mr: Erskine and Mr: Thompson— Neither of whom was at home— Mr: and Mrs: Erskine however were afterwards here— Every leisure moment of the day, from breakfast till supper, was employed upon my lecture, & Quinctilian.

15. I called this morning upon the Comptroller of the Treasury, who finally gave me an order for admitting the Power of Attorney from Blanchard, as sufficient— In consequence of which I received the Money at the Bank, and enclosed a check for it in a letter to Mr: Loud— The Suspension Bill finally pass’d, with the Amendments of the House, to the Amendments of the Senate— Mr: Quincy took me with him as far as the War-Office— In the Evening I finished my fair Copy of the 12th: of my Lectures, and read Quinctilian.

16. The Senate hitherto have done scarcely any thing from day to day but meet and adjourn— I remain at the Capitol only long enough to write, and dispatch my letters— Employing the remainder of the day, not unprofitably at home— Began my 14th: lecture— But spent the Evening below; with Mr: Boyd who was here.

17. On Motion of Mr: Tracy, the annual library Committee were chosen— Mr: Mitchill, Mr Baldwin and myself again— The Senate adjourned about one— But being engaged to dine at Mr: Madison’s, and having a long letter to write, I remained at the Capitol for that purpose untill 3— Rode with Dr: Logan to Mr: Madison’s; where was a company, of 19 at dinner—chiefly members of Congress— After dinner I called at Mr: Boyd’s; where I found Mrs: Johnson, and Dr: Ewell— This Gentleman, with Mr: Boyd came, and spent the Evening at Mr: Hellen’s— My customary studies were of course interrupted, the whole of this day.

18. Mr: Hellen’s second child, Walter, has been very unwell at intervals, ever since I have been here; and for some time before— In the middle of last Night he was seized violently, with the Hives, or Croup— Dr: Weems was immediately sent for; but was gone to Alexandria, to attend upon Mrs: Merry, who is ill there— An Emetic was however given to the child, which immediately relieved him and this forenoon he was apparently quite recovered— I attended in Senate; where before I arrived the Potowmac Bridge, bill had been read and referr’d to a select Committee— I wrote and sent a bill to Mrs: Adams— In the Evening I went, with Mrs: Johnson, and her daughters Kitty, Eliza and Adelaide to Dr: Thornton’s— I spent the Evening chiefly at Cards; with Captain Tingey and Mr:when we went out, we left the child apparently well— On our return we found him so ill, as to leave little hope of his life.

19. Dr: Weems—Mr: & Mrs: Hellen, and most of the family, were up the whole Night with the child; whose disease assumed from hour to hour an aspect threatening a fatal termination— I attended in the Senate, where nothing was done, and an early adjournment took place— On my way thither, I called at Mr: Boyd’s, and informed Eliza, of the distressing situation of the family— Immediately after dinner, Mrs: Johnson went to Mr: Boyd’s, and took with her Mr: Hellen’s infant daughter— The other child, Walter, expired just after 5. O’Clock this afternoon— His Death was easy, and had been gradually approaching from the morning— The Parents are in great distress— I wrote to Mrs: Adams, and enclosed the letter to Mr: Shaw.— Finished reading the old Testament in English—

20. I attended Mr: Hellen and the three girls; with Mr: Boyd, and Mr: T. B. Johnson to the Rock-Creek Church-Yard; where the child was buried— The funeral service was perform’d by Mr: Sayrs. We left the house at 2. P.M. and returned just at 5.— I saw the grave of Genl: Jackson, who was deposited there last March— There is no tomb-stone yet erected over him— In the Evening I returned to the studies, which have been interrupted almost the whole of this week.

21. I went to the Church at Georgetown to hear Mr: Sayrs, but he preached at the Capitol— I attended therefore the Methodist Meeting, and heard a Sermon by one preacher, and a prayer by another— The preacher was an indifferent Speaker; not remarkable even for fluency— The man who made the prayer had a fine sonorous voice, and a ready command of words. He produced much groaning of the Audience— Mr: and Mrs: Boyd dined with us— I employed all my leisure time in assiduous writing— Received a letter from Mrs: Adams which gives me great uneasiness.

22— There is so little done, and so little to do in the Senate; that we scarcely find means to put any thing upon the Journals.— I wrote to Mrs: Adams, and sent some packets of Papers— Called on Mr: Nourse at the Treasury, with some of the vouchers I have received, respecting the two boxes of Books, which I ship’d from Boston for the library of Congress— I have too much reason to apprehend that both of the vessels are lost— I am to call again upon Mr: Nourse to-morrow morning with my remaining papers, for the settlement of my account.— Evening at home writing as usual.

23. I called again this morning upon Mr: Nourse, and left at his Office the remainder of my vouchers.— The Senate adjourned before 12 O’Clock— After the adjournment I went into the lobby of the House of Representatives, and heard part of a debate upon some Resolutions offered by Mr: Elliot, and upon a bill to prohibit the importation of slaves into the United States.— Evening in my chamber writing, and reading Quinctilian.

24. Adjourned again in Senate very early—untill the day after to-morrow— Mr: Bradley busies himself much with his slave bill. He sent a copy of it to one of the principal leaders of the Abolition Society at Philadelphia; together with a letter— Mr: Burr’s projects occasion also much speculation; but appear not yet fully unfolded— I was going this afternoon with Catherine Johnson
to Mr: Boyd’s, when we met Mr: Van Rensselaer, Mr: Dana, and Mr: Clark, who were coming to visit at Mr: Hellen’s— We returned with them; and they spent the Evening with us— I received this Evening a letter from Mr: May of Alexandria, with the information that the schooner Mary and Eliza, from Boston for Alexandria, having on board most of the books I had sent for the library of Congress, foundered at sea two days after she sailed from Boston, about the 15th: of October— The Captain and Crew were taken from the wreck by a vessel bound to the West-Indies; whence they have returned to Boston.

25. Christmas day— Mr: Boyd spent it here— Mr: Caldwell was here on a visit— I was out only a few minutes in the Course of the day— Yet I neither read nor wrote so much as I ought— Finished however my 14th: Lecture, and began the 15th:

26. The Senate barely met and adjourned over to Monday— I attended a debate in the lobby of the House of Representatives— On the bill to prevent internal Sedition— The motion was to strike out the third Section; and it was struck out after a long struggle to retain it. On my return from the Capitol I called at Mr: Boyd’s— Spent the Evening in my chamber—writing—

27. Mr: and Mrs: Cutts were here this morning— As was Eliza Johnson from Mr Boyd’s— Mr: Stoddert spent the Evening here— I walked this afternoon with Catherine and Adelaide Johnson— I had consequently less leisure than I have usually enjoyed on the Saturday, and less time for writing.— That which I had was not lost.

28. Heard Mr: Sayrs at Georgetown; but the house was very thin, owing to the badness of the weather— Mr: Boyd, and his brother Walter, dined with us— He was called away soon after dinner; his child being ill— With some difficulty I accomplished my task of Saturday and Sunday, in writing, as I have undertaken it since the commencement of the Session.

29. After a week of much anxiety I received this morning a letter from my wife, by which I find that she and the children were well the 21st:— Mr: Clay of Kentuckey, appointed instead of Genl: Adair; and Mr: Reed of Maryland, who takes the place of Governor Wright took their seats in Senate this day— Adjourned about noon— Met Mr: Giles & Dr: Mitchill, in Committee on the Provisions to be made against Sedition and Treasonable projects— We came to no final determination. Evening spent in writing at home.

30. The Committee on the Potowmack Bridge Act, reported it without Amendment.— With the Georgetown Memorial against the Bridge— Written by Mr: Stoddert. Adjourned again about 1. I dined with Mr: Hellen at Mr: Boyd’s— And we spent most of the Evening there— So that when I came home I could not write.

31. This day completes one Month of time wasted by the Senate in doing nothing— The naval and army appropriation bills however are rapidly passing— After the adjournment I met Genl: Smith of Maryland in Committee, for a bill to prevent the enticement of Soldiers from their duty— But Dr: Mitchill the other member of the Committee not being present we could come to no decision.— Dined at the President’s, in Company with a company of members of Congress— All federalists— Captain Lewis also was there—just returned from the South Sea— Called at Mr: Boyd’s as I came home; but he was abroad— I finished the copy of my 15th: lecture; but have been hurried, and am much Dissatisfied with it.

Day. Rise with the Sun; shortly after 7— Read Homer’s Odyssey in Greek, and in Pope’s translation untill 9 or 10.— Breakfast. read in the English Bible, 4. Chapters— Walk to the Capitol— Attend in the Senate untill 1. or 2. After their adjournment return home— Read newspapers or write untill 4—from 5 to 9 in my chamber, writing my lectures or reading Quinctilian— Sup. Bed between 10. and 11.— Saturday’s & Sunday’s employed wholly on my Lectures.

The year which is now closed, has contained like every other portion of my life a mixture of good and of evil fortune; but on the whole gives me ample cause of gratitude to the giver of Good— On returning from Washington last April, I left my wife here, with the expectation, that she would remain here the summer through; and with hopes, which were disappointed— My wife returned, and preferr’d remaining with the children this Winter at Boston— My occupation through the year has been constant and assiduous— The duties of my Station at the University have employed me without intermission, since my return home last Spring, and shew me in prospect at least two years more, if bless’d with health, of as steady application— My health has been, taking the year through, better than for several preceding years— My domestic concerns improving—and in better condition now than at the Commencement of the year— My political prospects in a regular decline. My progress in Wisdom and Virtue, if any, far too small.
